problem.goal: To make a pasta dish similar to carbonara using bacon instead of guanciale and other non-traditional ingredients.

method.procedure:
1. Chop up bacon for use in the dish instead of guanciale.
2. Separate egg yolks from egg whites using the thumb trick or back and forth method.
3. Grate pecorino romano cheese into the egg yolks.
4. Add pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.
5. Boil spaghetti in salted water, ensuring not to break the noodles.
6. Cook the bacon and let it cool.
7. Add pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
8. Add cooked spaghetti directly from the water into the bacon pan.
9. Mix the sauce with the pasta in the bacon pan, using the heat from the noodles to thicken the sauce.
10. Add more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
11. Finish with additional pepper and pecorino or parmesan cheese.

result.outcome: The outcome is a pasta dish that resembles carbonara in appearance and texture, but is made using bacon instead of guanciale, and with non-traditional methods and ingredients, resulting in a distinct dish that is not true carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the ingredients for the dish that resembles carbonara.
problem.context: The process of cooking a dish that closely resembles spaghetti carbonara is about to begin.

method.tools: Knife, cutting board, measuring cups, mixing bowls
method.instructions: Gather all the necessary ingredients for the dish that resembles carbonara.
method.explanations: Having all the ingredients ready and measured before starting to cook ensures a smoother cooking process and helps avoid missing any components.
method.supplementary: Ensure all ingredients are fresh for the best flavor outcome.

result.outcome: All ingredients needed for the dish are prepared and ready for use in the cooking process.

problem.subgoal: Chop the bacon into small pieces.
problem.context: You have bacon that needs to be prepared for cooking.

method.instructions: Place the bacon on a cutting board and use a knife to chop it into small, even pieces.
method.explanations: Chopping the bacon into small pieces ensures that it will cook evenly and become crispy when cooked.
method.supplementary: Ensure the knife is sharp for easier and safer cutting.

result.outcome: The bacon is chopped into small pieces and ready for cooking.

problem.subgoal: Separate egg whites from yolks.
problem.context: Preparing to make a dish that requires only egg whites, avoiding the use of egg yolks.

method.instructions: Hold the yolk with your thumb while letting the egg white fall into a bowl.
method.explanations: Holding the yolk with your thumb allows the egg white to separate and fall into the bowl, leaving the yolk behind.
method.supplementary: Be careful not to mix any yolk with the whites, as it will affect the dish.

result.outcome: Egg whites are separated from the yolks and ready to be used in the recipe.

problem.subgoal: Shred Pecorino Romano cheese using a drill and screw.
problem.context: You have a block of Pecorino Romano cheese that you want to shred.

method.instructions: Insert a large screw into the drill. Secure the block of Pecorino Romano cheese. Use the drill with the screw to shred the cheese.
method.explanations: The drill with a screw acts as a makeshift grater, allowing you to shred the cheese more easily than by hand.
method.supplementary: Be cautious when using power tools with food. Ensure the screw is clean and food-safe.

result.outcome: The Pecorino Romano cheese is shredded, ready for use in cooking.

problem.subgoal: Grate cheese into the egg yolk and mix until creamy.
problem.context: The procedure is at the stage of preparing a creamy mixture with egg yolk.

method.instructions: Grate cheese into the egg yolk. Mix the ingredients until the mixture resembles a creamy filling.
method.explanations: Grating the cheese allows it to blend smoothly with the egg yolk, creating a creamy texture similar to a Cadbury cream egg filling.
method.supplementary: Use a fine grater for a smoother texture. Be careful not to overmix to avoid the mixture becoming too runny.

result.outcome: The result is a creamy mixture that resembles Cadbury cream egg filling, ready for the next step in the recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Cook spaghetti properly without breaking it.
problem.context: Preparing to cook spaghetti in boiling water.

method.instructions: Fill a pot with water and bring it to a boil. Add salt to the boiling water. Gently add 156 pieces of spaghetti to the pot without breaking them. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
method.explanations: Adding salt to the water enhances the flavor of the pasta. Stirring prevents the spaghetti from sticking together as it cooks.
method.supplementary: Do not break the spaghetti; it is considered improper and affects the texture and presentation.

result.outcome: The spaghetti will cook evenly without sticking together or breaking, maintaining its intended texture and appearance.

problem.subgoal: Combine cooked spaghetti with bacon and sauce ingredients.
problem.context: The spaghetti has been cooked in salted water and the bacon has been prepared. The sauce ingredients are ready for mixing.

method.instructions: Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot into the pan with the bacon using tongs. Add a bit of pasta water to the sauce ingredients in the pan.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water helps to emulsify the sauce, ensuring that the cheese melts smoothly and coats the pasta evenly. Transferring the noodles directly from the water allows them to retain some moisture, which helps in blending with the sauce.
method.supplementary: If you have dehydrated meatballs, set them aside before mixing them into the sauce. If you strain the spaghetti, remember to reserve some pasta water.

result.outcome: The spaghetti is mixed with the bacon and sauce ingredients, creating a cohesive and flavorful dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Finish the pasta dish by combining with sauce and garnishing.
problem.context: The spaghetti has been mixed with bacon and sauce ingredients, and the egg and cheese mixture is ready.

method.tools: Pan, Low heat, Pasta water, Pepper, Pecorino or Parmesan cheese
method.instructions: Add the sauce to the pasta in the pan. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. Add more pasta water to make it creamy. Finish by adding pepper and more Pecorino or Parmesan cheese.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water helps to create a creamy consistency and ensures the sauce coats the pasta evenly. Low heat can help thicken the sauce if desired. Pepper and cheese enhance the flavor of the dish.
method.supplementary: Using too much heat can scramble the eggs in the sauce. Adjust the amount of pasta water to achieve your desired consistency.

result.outcome: The pasta dish is creamy and well-coated with the sauce, garnished with pepper and cheese for enhanced flavor.

problem.subgoal: Understand the fragility of true carbonara.
problem.context: The speaker is discussing the challenges of making an authentic carbonara dish.

method.instructions: Avoid adding non-traditional ingredients to carbonara to maintain its authenticity.
method.explanations: Authentic carbonara has specific characteristics that can be altered by adding ingredients not traditionally used, such as peas.
method.supplementary: Be aware that even slight changes in ingredients or cooking method can affect the outcome of carbonara.

result.outcome: An understanding of the importance of preserving the traditional characteristics of carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Combine the spaghetti with the egg and cheese mixture to create a creamy sauce.
problem.context: The spaghetti has been mixed with bacon and sauce ingredients, and the egg and cheese mixture is ready.

method.tools: Pan, Low heat, Pasta water, Pepper, Pecorino or Parmesan cheese
method.instructions: Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta in the pan. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. Stir quickly to combine, adding more pasta water if needed to make it creamy. Finish by adding pepper and more Pecorino or Parmesan cheese.
method.explanations: The egg and cheese mixture, when combined with the hot pasta, creates a creamy sauce due to the heat from the pasta. Adding pasta water helps achieve the desired creaminess and ensures even coating. Stirring quickly prevents the eggs from scrambling.
method.supplementary: Be cautious with the heat to avoid scrambling the eggs. Adjust the amount of pasta water to get the preferred sauce consistency.

result.outcome: The pasta dish becomes creamy with the egg and cheese sauce coating the noodles, garnished with pepper and cheese for enhanced flavor.

problem.subgoal: Remove peas from a dish.
problem.context: The dish was initially prepared without any vegetables, and peas were mistakenly added.

method.instructions: Use a spoon to carefully pick out the peas from the dish.
method.explanations: A spoon allows you to scoop out individual peas without disturbing the rest of the dish too much.
method.supplementary: Be gentle to avoid mashing the peas and spreading them further into the dish.

result.outcome: The dish will be returned to its original vegetable-free state after the peas are removed.

method.instructions: List the necessary tools for the procedure.

method.supplementary: Ensure that tools are available and in good condition before proceeding.

result.outcome: A list of tools is prepared, ensuring that you are ready to begin the procedure efficiently.

problem.goal: To make a traditional spaghetti carbonara using bacon instead of guanciale.

method.procedure:
1. Slice thick-cut bacon into 3/4 inch pieces.
2. Heat a pan to medium and add a small amount of olive oil.
3. Add bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until crispy.
4. Boil water and season with a tablespoon of kosher salt.
5. Grate 3 ounces each of pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheese.
6. Mix 3 whole eggs and 2 egg yolks in a bowl.
7. Whisk the grated cheeses into the egg mixture.
8. Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture.
9. Add a quarter cup of pasta boiling water to the egg mixture to temper it.
10. Cook spaghetti in boiling water until slightly al dente.
11. Drain most of the bacon fat, leaving about 2 tablespoons in the pan, and turn off the heat.
12. Add cooked spaghetti to the pan with bacon.
13. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the warm pasta, stirring gently to create a creamy sauce.
14. If needed, add reserved pasta water to adjust sauce consistency.
15. Plate the carbonara and top with additional grated parmigiano reggiano and crispy bacon.

result.outcome: The outcome is a creamy, velvety spaghetti carbonara with a rich sauce made from eggs, cheese, and bacon, without using cream. The dish is topped with extra cheese and crispy bacon for added flavor and texture.

problem.subgoal: Understand the traditional ingredients for carbonara.
problem.context: The viewer wants to learn how to make an authentic carbonara dish.

method.instructions: Recognize that traditional carbonara does not include cream, peas, or ham.
method.explanations: Traditional carbonara is a simple dish that relies on a few key ingredients to achieve its flavor and texture. Adding ingredients like cream, peas, or ham is not part of the authentic recipe and alters the original taste.
method.supplementary: Carbonara is a classic Italian pasta dish made with eggs, cheese, pancetta, and pepper.

result.outcome: The viewer understands that authentic carbonara is made without cream, peas, or ham, and is ready to learn the traditional recipe.

problem.subgoal: Select and prepare the meat for spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The cook is explaining the choice of meat for making spaghetti carbonara in a way that is accessible to an American audience.

method.instructions: Use thick-cut bacon as a substitute for guanciale when making spaghetti carbonara.
method.explanations: Guanciale is the traditional meat used in spaghetti carbonara, but since it is not as readily available in the US, thick-cut bacon is a suitable alternative. It provides a similar texture and flavor profile that works well in the dish.
method.supplementary: Thick-cut bacon is recommended for a more authentic texture and flavor resembling guanciale.

result.outcome: Thick-cut bacon is chosen as the meat ingredient for the spaghetti carbonara, making the dish more accessible to an American audience.

problem.subgoal: Render bacon fat and crisp the bacon.
problem.context: The bacon needs to be prepared for the pasta dish by rendering the fat and crisping it.

method.instructions: Slice the bacon into thick pieces, about three-quarters of an inch. Heat a pan on medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Break the bacon into the pan and cook it slowly to render the fat and crisp the bacon.
method.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy and the fat to be used in cooking the pasta and as a garnish.
method.supplementary: Using olive oil is not traditional but can enhance the flavor of Italian dishes. Thick-cut bacon or pancetta is preferred for more texture.

result.outcome: The bacon will be crispy, with the fat rendered out, ready to be used in the pasta and as a garnish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Season the pasta water appropriately for carbonara.
problem.context: The bacon is rendering, and the pasta water is coming up to a boil.

method.tools: Kosher salt, tablespoon, pot with water
method.instructions: Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to four quarts of boiling pasta water.
method.explanations: Carbonara contains many salty ingredients, so less salt is needed in the pasta water to balance the overall saltiness of the dish.
method.supplementary: Adjust the amount of salt based on the salinity of other ingredients in your carbonara.

result.outcome: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual, suitable for cooking pasta for carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Grate pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheeses finely.
problem.context: The cheese selection has been made for making spaghetti carbonara, choosing pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano.

method.instructions: Use a cheese grater to finely grate approximately three ounces each of pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheeses.
method.explanations: Finely grated cheese is essential for the cheese to melt properly and integrate well into the spaghetti carbonara sauce.
method.supplementary: Ensure the parmigiano reggiano is authentic by checking the label for its origin from Italy. If a cheese grater isn't available, use the fine setting on a box grater.

result.outcome: You will have a finely grated mixture of pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheeses, ready to be used in the spaghetti carbonara recipe.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the egg and cheese mixture for spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheeses are grated and ready to be mixed with eggs for the carbonara sauce.

method.tools: Whisk, bowl, measuring scale for cheese, fresh black pepper grinder
method.instructions: Crack three whole eggs and separate two additional egg yolks into a bowl. Whisk them together. Gradually whisk in the grated pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheeses. Season generously with freshly ground black pepper and whisk until smooth.
method.explanations: The mixture of whole eggs and yolks provides richness without being overly heavy, and whisking them with cheese creates a creamy base for the sauce. Freshly ground black pepper adds essential flavor to the carbonara.
method.supplementary: The amount of black pepper is a matter of personal taste, so adjust according to preference. Ensure the mixture is smooth to avoid lumps in the sauce.

result.outcome: You will have a smooth, well-seasoned egg and cheese mixture ready to be combined with cooked pasta to make spaghetti carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Render bacon and prepare egg mixture for spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The bacon is cooking in a pan, releasing fat, and the egg mixture needs to be prepared for the carbonara sauce.

method.instructions: 1. Cook the bacon in the pan until the fat is rendered, turning occasionally. 2. Take a little boiling water and add it to the eggs, then whisk quickly to equalize temperatures and loosen the mixture. 3. Once the bacon is almost rendered, drop the spaghetti into boiling water. 4. Turn down the heat on the bacon, then drain and set aside some bacon for garnish. 5. Turn off the pan heat, drain most of the bacon fat, leaving about two tablespoons. 6. Cook the spaghetti for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente.
method.explanations: Adding boiling water to the eggs helps to equalize the temperature, preventing them from scrambling later and making the sauce smoother. Draining most of the bacon fat reduces greasiness while retaining flavor. Cooking spaghetti slightly al dente allows it to finish cooking with the sauce, absorbing more flavor.
method.supplementary: Do not add olive oil to the pasta water; it's unnecessary and doesn't prevent sticking. Use cheaper Italian pasta brands if preferred, as they often work just as well.

result.outcome: The bacon is rendered, and the egg mixture is ready, with a portion of bacon reserved for garnish and the spaghetti cooked to al dente in preparation for combining with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Combine the cooked pasta with the egg and cheese mixture to create a creamy carbonara sauce.
problem.context: The spaghetti is cooked and drained, and the egg and cheese mixture is ready to be combined with the pasta.

method.instructions: Use tongs to transfer the cooked spaghetti into a pan. Turn down the heat to a simmer. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta. Stir gently to combine, allowing the heat from the pasta to cook the eggs and create a creamy sauce.
method.explanations: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture gently, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The combination of pasta water, bacon fat, and the egg mixture creates an emulsion that coats the pasta.
method.supplementary: Be careful not to scramble the eggs by keeping the heat low and stirring gently. If the sauce needs to thicken, use a bain-marie technique by placing the pan over simmering water.

result.outcome: The pasta is coated with a velvety, creamy carbonara sauce that is not scrambled and is perfectly emulsified.

problem.subgoal: Finish the carbonara pasta by adjusting the sauce and plating.
problem.context: The pasta is mixed with the egg and cheese mixture, creating a creamy sauce. The sauce may be too thick and needs adjustment before serving.

method.instructions: If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it. Plate the pasta using tongs. Sprinkle with more Parmigiano-Reggiano and add crispy bacon on top.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water helps to loosen the sauce and enhance its creaminess without using cream. Additional cheese and bacon add flavor and texture to the dish.
method.supplementary: Ensure the sauce is not too thick by adjusting with pasta water. Adding extra cheese and bacon is optional but enhances the dish.

result.outcome: The carbonara pasta is perfectly creamy, plated with extra cheese and crispy bacon, ready to serve.

problem.subgoal: Finish rolling out the dough with a rolling pin.
problem.context: The dough is partially rolled out and needs to be flattened further.

method.instructions: Use the rolling pin to roll out the dough evenly.
method.explanations: The rolling pin helps to flatten and spread the dough evenly, ensuring a uniform thickness.
method.supplementary: Make sure to apply even pressure while rolling to avoid uneven thickness.

result.outcome: The dough is evenly rolled out, ready for the next step of the recipe.

method.procedure: 1. Gather the five main ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, and black pepper. Optionally, use garlic. 2. Bring water to a boil and twist the pasta before placing it in the water to prevent sticking. Add a small amount of salt to the water. Cook the pasta for 8 minutes. 3. Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and cutting it into half-centimeter chunks. Place it in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat. Add cracked garlic to the pan to infuse flavor. 4. Crack peppercorns in a pestle and mortar, sieve to separate the milder outer skin from the hotter inside part, and add pepper to the pan. 5. As the guanciale becomes golden, crack eggs into a bowl, add pecorino cheese, and whisk. 6. Remove garlic from the pan, turn off the heat, and transfer the pasta and some pasta water into the pan with the guanciale. Use the water to stop frying and create an emulsion with the fat. 7. Add the egg mixture to the pasta, tossing and adding more liquid as needed to achieve a creamy sauce. 8. Finish with more black pepper and serve with additional pecorino romano.

result.outcome: The outcome is a creamy, authentic spaghetti carbonara with rich flavors from the guanciale, pecorino romano, and carefully emulsified sauce. The dish is finished with pepper and additional cheese, creating a classic Italian pasta experience.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the ingredients for spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The procedure has just started, and no ingredients have been prepared yet.

method.instructions: Gather the necessary ingredients for spaghetti carbonara: pasta, cream, and bacon.
method.explanations: These are the basic ingredients needed to make spaghetti carbonara. Pasta is the main component, cream will create the sauce, and bacon adds flavor and texture.
method.supplementary: Ensure you have all ingredients on hand before starting the cooking process.

result.outcome: You will have all the necessary ingredients ready to start cooking spaghetti carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Gather the five ingredients needed for authentic Italian pasta carbonara.
problem.context: The process of making authentic Italian pasta carbonara is about to begin, and the first step is to gather the necessary ingredients.

method.instructions: Gather the following five ingredients: pasta, cheese (likely Pecorino Romano or Parmesan), bacon (or pancetta), eggs, and black pepper.
method.explanations: These ingredients are the fundamental components of a traditional carbonara. Each plays a crucial role in achieving the authentic taste and texture of the dish.
method.supplementary: Ensure the quality of the ingredients, especially the cheese and bacon, for the best flavor.

result.outcome: You will have all the ingredients needed to start preparing the pasta carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Understand the role of guanciale in cooking.
problem.context: The procedure involves selecting and preparing ingredients for a recipe that may require cured pork products.

method.instructions: Consider using guanciale for its unique qualities in recipes that require cured pork, ensuring it retains its fat content.
method.explanations: Guanciale is a cured pork product known for its rich fat content, which is essential for flavor in many recipes. It is similar to smoked bacon but has unique characteristics that enhance dishes.
method.supplementary: When purchasing guanciale, request that the fat is not trimmed off, as it is crucial for flavor.

result.outcome: A better understanding of how to select and use guanciale in recipes, ensuring the dish benefits from its rich fat content and flavor.

problem.subgoal: Choose the type of cheese for the dish.
problem.context: The cook is deciding on the type of cheese to use in the dish.

method.instructions: Select pecorino romano cheese for a classic flavor.
method.explanations: Pecorino romano is a traditional choice that provides a distinct and authentic taste.
method.supplementary: Consider the flavor profile you want for your dish when choosing cheese.

result.outcome: The dish will have a classic and authentic flavor with the use of pecorino romano cheese.

problem.subgoal: Gather ingredients for the dish.
problem.context: The cook is planning to prepare a dish but has not yet gathered the necessary ingredients.

method.instructions: Collect sheep's cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally, garlic.
method.explanations: These ingredients are essential for making the dish. Sheep's cheese adds a crumbly and salty flavor, while free-range organic eggs contribute to the richness. Pasta serves as the base, black pepper adds spice, and garlic is optional for additional flavor.
method.supplementary: Ensure that the cheese is crumbly and salty for the best taste. Using organic eggs enhances the dish's quality. Garlic is optional based on personal preference.

result.outcome: All necessary ingredients for the dish are gathered and ready to be used for cooking.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Cook the pasta without it sticking together.
problem.context: You have a pot of boiling water ready on the stove.

method.instructions: Grab the pasta with both hands and twist it as you add it to the boiling water. Add a small amount of salt to the water.
method.explanations: Twisting the pasta helps prevent it from sticking together as it cooks. Adding a small amount of salt enhances the flavor without making it overly salty, considering the saltiness of the other ingredients.
method.supplementary: Be careful when adding pasta to boiling water to avoid splashes. Use a timer to ensure the pasta is cooked for the correct duration.

result.outcome: The pasta is submerged in boiling water, cooking evenly without clumping together.

problem.subgoal: Render fat from guanciale in a pan.
problem.context: You have a piece of guanciale and a cold pan ready.

method.tools: Guanciale, knife, cutting board, skillet or pan, stove.
method.instructions: 1. Remove the skin from the guanciale. 2. Cut the guanciale into 1 cm slices. 3. Chop the slices into 0.5 cm chunks. 4. Place the chopped guanciale in a cold pan. 5. Turn the stove on to medium high heat.
method.explanations: Starting with a cold pan and gradually heating it helps render the fat from the guanciale slowly, allowing it to melt and cook evenly.
method.supplementary: Be careful when handling the knife to avoid injury. Ensure the pan is on a stable surface when heating.

result.outcome: The guanciale chunks will begin to render their fat, becoming golden and crispy as the pan heats up.

problem.subgoal: Prepare cracked pepper for carbonara.
problem.context: The cook is preparing ingredients for a carbonara sauce, having already cracked garlic in a pan to release its aroma.

method.instructions: Place peppercorns in a pestle and mortar and crack them. Use a sieve to separate the outer skin from the inside part of the peppercorn.
method.explanations: Cracking the peppercorns releases their flavors. Sifting them separates the milder outer skin from the hotter inner part, enhancing the heat in the dish.
method.supplementary: The outer skin of the peppercorn is milder, while the inner part is hotter and more suitable for carbonara.

result.outcome: You have a portion of cracked peppercorns with the hotter inner parts separated, ready to be used for a flavorful and spicy carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the egg mixture for the carbonara sauce.
problem.context: The guanciale is cooking and has reached a golden color. The next step is to prepare the egg mixture for the sauce.

method.instructions: Crack the egg into a bowl and add approximately 20 grams of pecorino cheese.
method.explanations: Eggs are delicate and must be handled carefully to avoid overcooking, which would result in unwanted texture similar to scrambled eggs. Adding pecorino cheese to the eggs helps to create a creamy sauce when mixed with the pasta.
method.supplementary: Ensure the bowl is clean and dry before cracking the egg into it to prevent contamination or unwanted moisture.

result.outcome: The egg mixture is ready with pecorino cheese incorporated, forming the base for the carbonara sauce.

problem.subgoal: Incorporate pasta and pasta water into the pan with guanciale fat.
problem.context: The guanciale has been cooked in a pan, rendering its fat, and the pasta is cooked in salted boiling water.

method.tools: Pan, pasta, pasta water, spoon or tongs.
method.instructions: 1. Remove the garlic from the pan with guanciale fat. 2. Turn off the heat under the pan. 3. Use a spoon or tongs to transfer the cooked pasta directly into the pan. 4. Add a bit of pasta water to the pan to stop the frying and help emulsify the sauce.
method.explanations: Removing the garlic prevents it from overpowering the dish. Adding pasta water to the pan stops the frying process and, combined with the guanciale fat, helps to create a creamy sauce due to the starches present in the water.
method.supplementary: Be careful when adding the pasta water to avoid splashes. Adjust the amount of water based on the desired sauce consistency.

result.outcome: The pasta is combined with the guanciale fat and pasta water, starting the process of creating a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Add cream to the pasta and guanciale mixture by emulsification.
problem.context: The pasta has been combined with the guanciale fat and pasta water, stopping the frying process and beginning the creation of the sauce.

method.instructions: Wait until the frying sound stops, indicating that the pasta has absorbed some liquid and the frying has ceased. Then, add the egg mixture to the pan while tossing the pasta to combine.
method.explanations: The absence of the frying sound means the liquid has been absorbed by the pasta, allowing the egg mixture to be added without scrambling. Tossing helps emulsify the ingredients, creating a creamy sauce.
method.supplementary: Ensure the heat is off to prevent scrambling the eggs, and add the egg mixture gradually while continuously tossing the pasta.

result.outcome: The egg mixture is combined with the pasta, guanciale, and pasta water, creating a creamy carbonara sauce through emulsification.

problem.subgoal: Serve the spaghetti carbonara and finish with additional pepper and pecorino.
problem.context: The spaghetti carbonara has been prepared with a creamy sauce created by emulsifying eggs, cheese, guanciale, and pasta water.

method.tools: Serving platter, spoon, pepper grinder, grater.
method.instructions: Transfer the spaghetti carbonara onto a serving platter. Add additional ground pepper and grate pecorino cheese on top before serving.
method.explanations: The additional pepper enhances the flavor, and the pecorino cheese adds a final touch of richness and authenticity to the dish.
method.supplementary: Serve immediately to enjoy the dish at its best texture and flavor. Encourage diners to start eating without delay.

result.outcome: The spaghetti carbonara is served attractively with a final touch of pepper and pecorino, ready to be enjoyed by diners.

problem.subgoal: Commenting on the final result of a dish.
problem.context: The dish has been prepared and is ready for presentation or consumption.

method.instructions: Express satisfaction and admiration for the dish.
method.explanations: The expression is used to convey delight and appreciation for the successful outcome of the cooking process.
method.supplementary: This comment is subjective and reflects personal satisfaction with the dish.

result.outcome: The speaker expresses happiness and contentment with the completed dish, suggesting it has been made successfully and is appealing.

problem.goal: To prepare authentic Italian Carbonara pasta.

method.procedure:
1. Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter of water. Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes without adding oil, stirring occasionally.
2. Cut guanciale (pork cheek) or pancetta into chunks. Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it begins to render fat.
3. In a bowl, beat two eggs (using only the yolks for richness). Add grated Parmesan or Pecorino cheese and abundant black pepper to the eggs, mixing well.
4. Optionally remove excess fat from the cooked guanciale using a paper towel.
5. Once pasta is al dente, drain and add it to the pan with guanciale, mixing to coat the pasta with the rendered fat.
6. Remove the pan from heat and add the egg mixture to the pasta, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
7. Serve the pasta with additional grated Parmesan or Pecorino cheese and a sprinkle of black pepper.

result.outcome: The outcome is a creamy and authentic Carbonara pasta, with a rich sauce made from eggs, cheese, and rendered guanciale fat, without any added cream. The dish is flavorful, featuring the distinct taste of guanciale and the sharpness of Pecorino or Parmesan cheese, with a touch of black pepper for spice.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Cook pasta in boiling water.
problem.context: You have a pot of boiling water ready for cooking pasta.

method.instructions: Add 10 grams of salt per liter of boiling water. Then add the pasta (spaghettoni) to the boiling water. Stir occasionally while cooking for about 10 minutes.
method.explanations: Adding salt to the water enhances the flavor of the pasta. Stirring prevents the pasta from sticking together. Cooking for 10 minutes ensures the pasta is properly cooked to the desired texture.
method.supplementary: Do not add oil to the boiling water as it is unnecessary and can prevent sauce from sticking to the pasta later.

result.outcome: The pasta is cooked to the desired texture and is ready for further preparation or serving.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the pork cheek (guanciale) by cutting it into chunks.
problem.context: The original carbonara recipe requires preparation of the pork cheek (guanciale) for cooking.

method.instructions: Cut the guanciale (pork cheek) into large chunks.
method.explanations: Guanciale is a traditional ingredient in carbonara and is known for its tenderness and flavor. Cutting it into chunks allows it to cook evenly and release its flavors into the dish.
method.supplementary: Pancetta can be used as an alternative if guanciale is not available.

result.outcome: You will have chunks of guanciale ready to be used in the carbonara recipe.

problem.subgoal: Start making the sauce with olive oil and guanciale.
problem.context: You have gathered all the ingredients needed to make the sauce.

method.instructions: Pour good olive oil into a pan, then add guanciale to the pan.
method.explanations: The olive oil provides a base for the sauce, and the guanciale adds flavor as it cooks and releases its fat.
method.supplementary: Ensure the pan is heated to allow the guanciale to cook properly and release its flavors.

result.outcome: The olive oil and guanciale are combined in the pan, forming the base of the sauce.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the cheese and egg mixture for the sauce.
problem.context: You have a bowl ready for mixing, and you need to start preparing the sauce for a dish.

method.instructions: Separate the yolks from the eggs and place the yolks in the bowl. Add grated Parmesan cheese (and optionally Pecorino cheese) and abundant pepper. Stir the mixture thoroughly.
method.explanations: The egg yolks provide richness and help create a creamy texture for the sauce. Parmesan and Pecorino add flavor, while pepper adds a bit of spice.
method.supplementary: Do not add any cream to the mixture, as it is not part of the traditional preparation method.

result.outcome: You will have a well-mixed cheese and egg yolk mixture that serves as the base for the sauce.

problem.subgoal: Adjust the cooking time of the pasta based on its texture.
problem.context: The pasta is still too stiff after the initial cooking time.

method.instructions: Put the pasta back into the boiling water for an additional 3 to 4 minutes.
method.explanations: The pasta is still stiff, indicating it is undercooked. Adding more time will allow it to soften to the desired texture.
method.supplementary: Check the pasta's texture periodically to avoid overcooking.

result.outcome: The pasta becomes softer and reaches the desired texture for serving.

problem.subgoal: Remove excess fat from cooked bacon.
problem.context: The bacon has been cooked and there is excess fat in the pan.

method.instructions: Use a paper towel to absorb the excess fat in the pan.
method.explanations: The paper towel will soak up the liquid fat, making it easier to remove from the pan.
method.supplementary: Be careful not to burn yourself with the hot fat.

result.outcome: The excess fat is absorbed by the paper towel, leaving less fat in the pan.

problem.subgoal: Transfer cooked pasta to a bowl and let it cool.
problem.context: The pasta has been cooked in salted boiling water and is ready for further preparation.

method.instructions: Switch off the heat and transfer the cooked pasta from the pot to a bowl.
method.explanations: Turning off the heat stops the cooking process, and transferring the pasta to a bowl allows it to cool down, preventing overcooking and making it easier to handle for the next steps.
method.supplementary: Ensure the pasta is drained properly before transferring to prevent excess water from affecting the dish.

result.outcome: The cooked pasta is now in a bowl, cooling down and ready for the next step in the recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Coat pasta with egg and cheese mixture to form a sauce.
problem.context: The cooked pasta is in a bowl and has cooled slightly. The egg and cheese mixture is prepared and ready to be combined with the pasta.

method.instructions: Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta in the bowl. Stir the pasta quickly and thoroughly to coat it evenly with the mixture.
method.explanations: The heat from the pasta is crucial for cooking the egg mixture gently, turning it into a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Stirring ensures even coating and prevents the eggs from cooking too quickly in one spot.
method.supplementary: Make sure the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs. The pasta should be warm enough to cook the eggs gently.

result.outcome: The pasta is evenly coated with a creamy sauce formed by the egg and cheese mixture, without any scrambled eggs.

problem.subgoal: Add final embellishments to the carbonara.
problem.context: The pasta is coated with a creamy sauce formed by the egg and cheese mixture, achieving a classic carbonara texture without scrambled eggs.

method.instructions: Sprinkle Parmesan or Pecorino cheese over the pasta. Add a touch of pepper for additional flavor.
method.explanations: Adding cheese and pepper at the end enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, providing a final layer of taste and visual appeal.
method.supplementary: Choose between Parmesan or Pecorino based on your preference. Be careful not to overwhelm the dish with too much cheese or pepper.

result.outcome: The carbonara is garnished with cheese and pepper, enhancing its flavor and achieving a traditional presentation.

problem.subgoal: Taste the dish to ensure it is prepared properly.
problem.context: The cooking process is complete, and the dish is ready for tasting.

method.instructions: Take a small portion of the dish and taste it.
method.explanations: Tasting the dish allows you to evaluate the flavors and ensure it meets your desired taste and quality standards.
method.supplementary: Ensure the dish is cool enough to taste safely to avoid burns.

result.outcome: You will have a better understanding of the dish's flavor profile and can make any necessary adjustments before serving.

subtitles.text: Hey folks,

About a year ago,
a group of real-deal Italian chefs

savagely critiqued some of the biggest
Carbonara videos on the Internet.

And as you may remember,
my entry was not very well received.

Since then I've dreamt of
nothing but Redemption.

So today we're gonna take a crack at
two different versions of Carbonara,
a real-deal old-school Italian version,

and a more modern less traditional
version that's sure to piss em' off!
Let's get down to basics.
[Intro Music]
All right. So before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make "Carbonara"

which by definition, is made with
"Guanciale", a type of cured pork jowl.
It is very delicious but a little hard to find.

So if you can't find it, you can sub
with Pancetta if you're in a pinch.

I've got maybe a half-pound here that
I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks

and then set aside to make one of the essential
elements of any Carbonara dish: The Egg Slurry.

Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes 3 large eggs,
and 1 egg yolk for a little added richness.

And then it's time to finely grate and
measure out 4 ounces of cheese.

Truly traditional "Carbonara" uses
100% Pecorino Romano Cheese,

but is commonly balanced out
with Parmigiano-Reggiano.

If you want it a little less sharp and
a little more nutty, I'm going for a 50/50 ratio.
Into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs.

We're then going to beat this whole affair
together with a fork until homogenous.

The only other thing you're gonna want to add is
a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.

We're not adding any salt yet
because "Guanciale" can vary in saltiness,
and we don't want to oversalt our dish.

Beat that together until well incorporated and
then it's time to head over to the Stovetop,
where we are introducing the "Guanciale" to a cold pan.
We're then gonna turn the heat to medium.

This is gonna cook the "Guanciale" more slowly
and allow more of its fat to render out
which in traditional "Carbonara" is a good thing.
Once it is fully cooked but not too crispy,

we're gonna kill the heat
and put our pasta in the hot tub.

The water is "Salato come il mare",
or as salty as the sea.

And we gotta keep it moving to
prevent it from sticking together.
And then a cool trick to determine pasta's doneness
is to take out a strand and eat it to see if it's done.
Don't throw it against the wall, you friggin' weirdo.

As you can see, our pork jowl has
almost entirely stopped bubbling.
That's exactly where we want it to be.
And as soon as the pasta is done,

we're dumping it directly into
the saute pan with the "Guanciale".

Once all the pasta is being added
we're gonna toss it around in the pan,

ensuring that it is evenly
covered in all that "Guanciale" fat.
And you wanna work quickly here.

Because the only thing that's going to
cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy
is the residual heat from the Pasta.

So waste no time getting the egg and cheese
mixture in there and then agitate rigorously!

This is going to help emulsify the sauce
and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling.

If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like,
you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a 1/4 cup.
But ideally, it should look just like this.

Now we're gonna taste for seasoning,
(Mine needs a little bit of salt).
Then you can optionally toss the pasta.

This is gonna help aerate it a little bit,
get that sauce super creamy!
And then, finally it's time to plate up!!

I like to use a carving fork to twirl the
pasta into a giant cylinder like this one
for presentation on a long narrow plate.

We are then of course going to
want to top this Hedonistic Helix

with the remaining "Guanciale"
from the bottom of the pan
along with any remnants of that creamy sauce!
And there you have it folks!
I'm going to say it one last time:

"Carbonara",
in its purest most authentic and traditional form.

Unless of course I got something
wrong, in which case I'm in trouble.

But at this point I'm gonna ask all Italians to leave
the room, because it's time to make carbonara.

This starts very much the same way
with Parmesan and Romano cheese

grated into a bowl along with
3 eggs and 1 egg yolk,

beaten together with a few healthy
twists of freshly ground black pepper.

Now when most Americans make
Carbonara, they reach for the bacon.

If you can't find "Guanciale" or "Pancetta"
and you got to use bacon,
just go for the thick-cut stuff.

And likewise we're gonna slice about
1/2 a pound of it into big ol' chunks.

Then likewise, we're gonna start
these guys off in a cold pan,

because we want to render out as much fat
as possible, but not for the same reason.
You'll also notice that I'm using a nonstick pan.

And that's because in the stainless, bacon can leave
a lot of fond on the bottom of the pot.

Which for once we don't want, as it might
make our final pasta look kind of dirty.

Once the bacon is fully cooked and the fat
rendered out, we are going to strain it.

Because this version of Carbonara
is going to have a much lighter sauce.

We're just going to strain off all but
about 2 tbsp worth of bacon fat,
which we're gonna leave in the pan.

And then we're gonna return it over medium-low heat to
add the most egregious ingredient of all: garlic.

This is considered sacrilege
in the world of "Carbonara",

but I think it tastes really
really good, and so will you.

We're just sautéing for 1 minute
until fragrant before killing the heat.

Next up, I see far too many people just
dump pasta out of the box in the water
which inevitably leads to disaster.

Give this a shot, where you dump
the pasta into the palm of your hand

and then pull it out using
your hand, like a real gentleman.

And as you can see, this time
I'm going with Bucatini.

Next up, just like last time we're adding
the pasta directly to the pan,

but this time we're gonna add about
1/3 of a cup of starchy pasta water
which is gonna help make a cohesive sauce.

Then we are adding the egg
and cheese mixture to the party.

And if you find yourself in a pickle like this where
your pan is too small to toss the pasta, no biggie!
Just dump it back into the emptied pasta pot.

Just make sure that you keep it moving
because there's a lot of residual heat in here

and we don't want to end up with
pasta and scrambled eggs.

So just wildly agitate that around
and then it's time to taste for seasoning!

Add salt and pepper as necessary
and assess your sauce's thickness.

If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it
with a little bit of finely-grated Parmesan.

Just add maybe another 1/4 oz
or so and mix rigorously.
And now it's time to plate up!!
And one thing you'll notice about this Carbonara

is that the sauce is much lighter
because it has a lot less fat.

It also stays creamier longer and
won't congeal as quickly as "Carbonara".

And the Bucatini, while a little bit difficult to
get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely.

Whichever version of Carbonara
you decide to make for yourself,

I hope this has shown you how easy it can be,
so long as you follow a few simple tricks!

Now go out there, get some pasta,
and start rolling your R's.

and assess your sauce's thickness.

If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it
with a little bit of finely-grated Parmesan.

Just add maybe another 1/4 oz
or so and mix rigorously.
And now it's time to plate up!!
And one thing you'll notice about this Carbonara

is that the sauce is much lighter
because it has a lot less fat.

It also stays creamier longer and
won't congeal as quickly as "Carbonara".

And the Bucatini, while a little bit difficult to
get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely.

Whichever version of Carbonara
you decide to make for yourself,

I hope this has shown you how easy it can be,
so long as you follow a few simple tricks!

Now go out there, get some pasta,
and start rolling your R's.

common_steps.title: Introduction
common_steps.text:
Hey folks, About a year ago,
a group of real-deal Italian chefs savagely critiqued some of the biggest
Carbonara videos on the Internet. And as you may remember,
my entry was not very well received. Since then I've dreamt of
nothing but Redemption. So today we're gonna take a crack at
two different versions of Carbonara, a real-deal old-school Italian version, and a more modern less traditional
version that's sure to piss em' off! Let's get down to basics.
common_steps.explanation: The introduction provides context and motivation for the video, explaining the purpose and what will be covered.

common_steps.title: Prepare guanciale
common_steps.text:
All right. So before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make "Carbonara" which by definition, is made with
"Guanciale", a type of cured pork jowl. It is very delicious but a little hard to find. So if you can't find it, you can sub
with Pancetta if you're in a pinch. I've got maybe a half-pound here that
I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks and then set aside to make one of the essential
elements of any Carbonara dish: The Egg Slurry.
common_steps.explanation: The segment focuses on preparing guanciale, which is a key ingredient in Carbonara, by cutting it into chunks.

common_steps.title: Prepare egg and cheese mixture
common_steps.text:
Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes 3 large eggs,
and 1 egg yolk for a little added richness. And then it's time to finely grate and
measure out 4 ounces of cheese. Truly traditional "Carbonara" uses
100% Pecorino Romano Cheese, but is commonly balanced out
with Parmigiano-Reggiano. If you want it a little less sharp and
a little more nutty, I'm going for a 50/50 ratio. Into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs.
common_steps.explanation: This segment involves creating the egg and cheese mixture, which is essential for the carbonara sauce.

common_steps.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture
common_steps.text:
We're then going to beat this whole affair
together with a fork until homogenous. The only other thing you're gonna want to add is
a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper. We're not adding any salt yet
because "Guanciale" can vary in saltiness, and we don't want to oversalt our dish.
common_steps.explanation: The segment shows mixing the egg and cheese mixture with black pepper to prepare it for the pasta.

common_steps.title: Prepare guanciale
common_steps.text:
Beat that together until well incorporated and
then it's time to head over to the Stovetop, where we are introducing the "Guanciale" to a cold pan. We're then gonna turn the heat to medium. This is gonna cook the "Guanciale" more slowly
and allow more of its fat to render out which in traditional "Carbonara" is a good thing. Once it is fully cooked but not too crispy,
common_steps.explanation: This segment focuses on cooking the guanciale to render out the fat, which is crucial for the dish.

common_steps.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta
common_steps.text:
we're gonna kill the heat
and put our pasta in the hot tub. The water is "Salato come il mare",
or as salty as the sea. And we gotta keep it moving to
prevent it from sticking together. And then a cool trick to determine pasta's doneness is to take out a strand and eat it to see if it's done.
common_steps.explanation: This segment describes boiling salted water and cooking the pasta until al dente, a key step in making carbonara.

common_steps.title: Combine pasta with guanciale
common_steps.text:
Don't throw it against the wall, you friggin' weirdo. As you can see, our pork jowl has
almost entirely stopped bubbling. That's exactly where we want it to be. And as soon as the pasta is done, we're dumping it directly into
the saute pan with the "Guanciale". Once all the pasta is being added
we're gonna toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly
covered in all that "Guanciale" fat.
common_steps.explanation: The cooked pasta is combined with the guanciale in the pan, infusing it with flavor.

common_steps.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture
common_steps.text:
And you wanna work quickly here. Because the only thing that's going to
cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the Pasta. So waste no time getting the egg and cheese
mixture in there and then agitate rigorously! This is going to help emulsify the sauce
and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling.
common_steps.explanation: The pasta is mixed with the egg and cheese mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce.

common_steps.title: Adjust seasoning and serve
common_steps.text:
If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like,
you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a 1/4 cup. But ideally, it should look just like this. Now we're gonna taste for seasoning,
(Mine needs a little bit of salt). Then you can optionally toss the pasta. This is gonna help aerate it a little bit,
get that sauce super creamy! And then, finally it's time to plate up!! I like to use a carving fork to twirl the
pasta into a giant cylinder like this one for presentation on a long narrow plate. We are then of course going to
want to top this Hedonistic Helix with the remaining "Guanciale"
from the bottom of the pan along with any remnants of that creamy sauce! And there you have it folks! I'm going to say it one last time: "Carbonara",
in its purest most authentic and traditional form.
common_steps.explanation: The final touches include adjusting seasoning, plating, and serving the dish, ensuring it is flavorful and well-presented.

common_steps.title: Transition to modern version
common_steps.text:
Unless of course I got something
wrong, in which case I'm in trouble. But at this point I'm gonna ask all Italians to leave
the room, because it's time to make carbonara.
common_steps.explanation: The transition marks the end of the traditional version and the start of the modern version.

common_steps.title: Modern carbonara version
common_steps.text:
This starts very much the same way
with Parmesan and Romano cheese grated into a bowl along with
3 eggs and 1 egg yolk, beaten together with a few healthy
twists of freshly ground black pepper. Now when most Americans make
Carbonara, they reach for the bacon. If you can't find "Guanciale" or "Pancetta"
and you got to use bacon, just go for the thick-cut stuff. And likewise we're gonna slice about
1/2 a pound of it into big ol' chunks. Then likewise, we're gonna start
these guys off in a cold pan, because we want to render out as much fat
as possible, but not for the same reason. You'll also notice that I'm using a nonstick pan. And that's because in the stainless, bacon can leave
a lot of fond on the bottom of the pot. Which for once we don't want, as it might
make our final pasta look kind of dirty. Once the bacon is fully cooked and the fat
rendered out, we are going to strain it. Because this version of Carbonara
is going to have a much lighter sauce. We're just going to strain off all but
about 2 tbsp worth of bacon fat, which we're gonna leave in the pan. And then we're gonna return it over medium-low heat to
add the most egregious ingredient of all: garlic. This is considered sacrilege
in the world of "Carbonara", but I think it tastes really
really good, and so will you. We're just sautéeing for 1 minute
until fragrant before killing the heat. Next up, I see far too many people just
dump pasta out of the box in the water which inevitably leads to disaster. Give this a shot, where you dump
the pasta into the palm of your hand and then pull it out using
your hand, like a real gentleman. And as you can see, this time
I'm going with Bucatini. Next up, just like last time we're adding
the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about
1/3 of a cup of starchy pasta water which is gonna help make a cohesive sauce. Then we are adding the egg
and cheese mixture to the party. And if you find yourself in a pickle like this where
your pan is too small to toss the pasta, no biggie! Just dump it back into the emptied pasta pot. Just make sure that you keep it moving
because there's a lot of residual heat in here and we don't want to end up with
pasta and scrambled eggs. So just wildly agitate that around
and then it's time to taste for seasoning! Add salt and pepper as necessary
and assess your sauce's thickness. If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it
with a little bit of finely-grated Parmesan. Just add maybe another 1/4 oz
or so and mix rigorously. And now it's time to plate up!! And one thing you'll notice about this Carbonara is that the sauce is much lighter
because it has a lot less fat. It also stays creamier longer and
won't congeal as quickly as "Carbonara". And the Bucatini, while a little bit difficult to
get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely. Whichever version of Carbonara
you decide to make for yourself, I hope this has shown you how easy it can be,
so long as you follow a few simple tricks! Now go out there, get some pasta,
and start rolling your R's.
common_steps.explanation: This segment covers the preparation of a modern version of carbonara, using bacon and garlic, and discusses differences in technique and flavor.

problem.goal: To make two versions of Carbonara: traditional and modern.

method.procedure:
1. Slice 1/2 pound of Guanciale or Pancetta into chunks.
2. Beat 3 large eggs and 1 egg yolk in a bowl.
3. Grate 4 ounces of cheese, using a 50/50 mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano.
4. Mix the cheese and eggs with freshly ground black pepper to create an egg slurry.
5. Cook Guanciale in a cold pan on medium heat until fat is rendered and meat is cooked but not crispy.
6. Cook pasta in salty water until al dente.
7. Combine cooked pasta with Guanciale in the pan.
8. Quickly add egg slurry to pasta and agitate to emulsify the sauce, adding pasta water if needed.
9. Adjust seasoning with salt.
10. Plate the pasta and top with remaining Guanciale and sauce.
11. For modern Carbonara, repeat steps 1-4 using bacon and a nonstick pan.
12. Strain cooked bacon, leaving 2 tablespoons of fat.
13. Add garlic to the pan and sauté for 1 minute.
14. Cook Bucatini pasta and add to the pan with bacon.
15. Add 1/3 cup pasta water and egg slurry.
16. Toss pasta to coat and adjust seasoning.
17. Plate and serve.

result.outcome: The result is two types of Carbonara: a traditional version with a creamy, rich sauce and Guanciale, and a modern version with a lighter sauce and bacon, enhanced with garlic and served with Bucatini pasta.

problem.subgoal: Introduce the purpose and approach of the Carbonara cooking video.
problem.context: The video is starting, and the presenter is setting the stage for what will be covered.

method.instructions: Introduce the concept of revisiting Carbonara recipes and explain the two versions that will be prepared.
method.explanations: The presenter had previously received criticism from Italian chefs on their Carbonara recipe, and now they aim to redeem themselves by exploring both traditional and modern versions.
method.supplementary: The video aims to both honor traditional Carbonara and explore a modern twist, possibly provoking traditionalists.

result.outcome: The audience understands the presenter's motivation and the dual approach to making Carbonara in the video.

problem.subgoal: Prepare guanciale or pancetta for Carbonara.
problem.context: Before making Carbonara, guanciale or pancetta needs to be prepared as it is a key ingredient.

method.instructions: Cut the guanciale or pancetta into relatively sizable chunks.
method.explanations: Guanciale is a traditional ingredient in Carbonara, known for its flavor. Pancetta can be used as a substitute if guanciale is unavailable.
method.supplementary: Ensure the chunks are not too small to retain their texture and flavor during cooking.

result.outcome: You will have chunks of guanciale or pancetta ready to be used in the Carbonara dish.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the egg and cheese mixture for Carbonara sauce.
problem.context: The process of making Carbonara sauce is underway, and the cook is preparing the egg and cheese mixture.

method.instructions: Crack 3 large eggs and 1 egg yolk into a medium bowl or measuring cup. Grate and measure out 4 ounces of cheese, using a 50/50 mixture of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano if desired. Combine the beaten eggs with the grated cheese.
method.explanations: The additional egg yolk adds richness to the sauce. Pecorino Romano is traditional for Carbonara, but blending it with Parmigiano-Reggiano balances the sharpness with a nutty flavor. The eggs and cheese will form the base of the Carbonara sauce.
method.supplementary: Ensure the cheese is finely grated for smooth incorporation into the sauce. Adjust the cheese ratio according to taste preference.

result.outcome: A well-mixed egg and cheese base ready to be incorporated into the Carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Beat egg and cheese mixture until homogenous and add black pepper.
problem.context: The egg and cheese have been combined in a bowl, but they have not yet been mixed to a homogenous consistency or seasoned.

method.instructions: Use a fork to beat the egg and cheese mixture until it is smooth and homogenous. Add freshly ground black pepper to the mixture.
method.explanations: Beating the mixture ensures the eggs and cheese are fully combined, creating a smooth texture. The black pepper adds flavor to the sauce.
method.supplementary: Do not add salt at this stage to avoid oversalting, as the guanciale will contribute additional saltiness.

result.outcome: A smooth, homogenous egg and cheese mixture seasoned with black pepper, ready for the next step in making Carbonara sauce.

problem.subgoal: Cook guanciale slowly to render fat.
problem.context: Ingredients are prepared and ready to be cooked. The guanciale is raw and needs to be rendered for carbonara.

method.instructions: Place guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium. Cook until fully cooked but not too crispy.
method.explanations: Starting in a cold pan and cooking slowly allows the fat in the guanciale to render out effectively, which is desirable for making carbonara.
method.supplementary: Ensure the guanciale is not too crispy to maintain the desired texture for carbonara.

result.outcome: The guanciale is cooked and has rendered out its fat, ready to be used in the carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Cook pasta to the desired doneness.
problem.context: The water is boiling and seasoned with salt, ready for pasta cooking.

method.instructions: Turn off the heat and add pasta to the salted boiling water. Stir continuously to prevent sticking. Taste a strand to check for doneness.
method.explanations: Turning off the heat prevents overcooking. Stirring ensures pasta doesn’t clump together. Tasting is the most reliable way to check if the pasta is cooked to your liking.
method.supplementary: Ensure the water is as salty as the sea for proper seasoning. Be cautious of hot water when stirring.

result.outcome: Pasta is cooked to the desired texture and is ready to be used in your dish.

problem.subgoal: Combine cooked pasta with rendered guanciale fat.
problem.context: The guanciale has been cooked and rendered, and the pasta is cooked to the desired doneness.

method.instructions: Dump the cooked pasta directly into the saute pan with the rendered guanciale. Toss the pasta in the pan to coat it evenly with the guanciale fat.
method.explanations: Tossing the pasta with the guanciale fat ensures that the pasta is evenly coated with the flavorful fat, which is essential for the taste and texture of Carbonara.
method.supplementary: Be careful when transferring the pasta to avoid splattering hot fat. Ensure the pasta is well-drained before adding to the pan to prevent excess water from diluting the fat.

result.outcome: The pasta is evenly coated with the flavorful fat from the guanciale, ready for further steps in making Carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Incorporate egg and cheese mixture into the hot pasta to create a creamy sauce.
problem.context: The cooked pasta has been combined with rendered guanciale fat and is hot, ready to receive the egg and cheese mixture to form the Carbonara sauce.

method.tools: Bowl with egg and cheese mixture, pasta with guanciale in pan, tongs or spoon
method.instructions: Quickly add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot pasta in the pan. Stir vigorously to emulsify and coat the pasta.
method.explanations: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, creating a smooth and creamy sauce. Stirring vigorously helps emulsify the sauce and prevents the eggs from curdling.
method.supplementary: Work quickly to prevent the egg and cheese mixture from curdling. Use the heat of the pasta, not direct heat, to cook the sauce.

result.outcome: The pasta is coated in a smooth, creamy Carbonara sauce that is properly emulsified and not curdled.

problem.subgoal: Final adjustments and plating of Carbonara.
problem.context: The pasta has been mixed with the egg and cheese mixture to form a creamy Carbonara sauce, but the dish needs final seasoning adjustments and plating.

method.instructions: Check the sauce's consistency, adding pasta water if needed. Taste and adjust seasoning with salt. Toss the pasta to aerate and make it creamy. Use a carving fork to twirl the pasta into a cylinder and plate it. Top with remaining guanciale and sauce.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water can adjust the sauce's consistency if it's too thick. Tossing aerates the pasta, enhancing the creaminess. Twirling the pasta with a fork creates an aesthetically pleasing presentation.
method.supplementary: Be cautious with salt as guanciale is salty. Twirling the pasta enhances presentation.

result.outcome: The Carbonara is plated attractively on a long narrow plate, topped with guanciale and sauce, ready to serve.

problem.subgoal: Prepare to cook carbonara.
problem.context: The cook is about to start making carbonara and is jokingly addressing the audience.

method.instructions: Begin the process of making carbonara.
method.explanations: The cook is introducing the next step in the cooking process, which is making carbonara.
method.supplementary: The cook humorously asks Italians to leave the room, possibly referencing the contentious nature of traditional carbonara recipes.

result.outcome: The cook is ready to start the carbonara recipe.

problem.subgoal: Make Carbonara with a lighter sauce using bacon.
problem.context: The ingredients for Carbonara are prepared, including grated Parmesan and Romano cheese, eggs, and thick-cut bacon sliced into chunks.

method.instructions: 1. Start with Parmesan and Romano cheese grated into a bowl. 2. Beat together with 3 eggs and 1 egg yolk, adding freshly ground black pepper. 3. Slice 1/2 pound thick-cut bacon into chunks. 4. Cook bacon in a cold nonstick pan to render fat, then strain. 5. Leave 2 tbsp of bacon fat in the pan, add garlic, and sauté for 1 minute. 6. Cook Bucatini pasta and add to the pan with 1/3 cup starchy pasta water. 7. Add egg and cheese mixture, toss, and adjust seasoning. 8. If needed, add more finely-grated Parmesan to thicken sauce. 9. Plate the pasta.
method.explanations: Starting bacon in a cold pan helps render more fat, which is needed for the sauce. Using a nonstick pan avoids fond that could make the pasta look dirty. Adding starchy pasta water helps emulsify the sauce. Keep the pasta moving to prevent scrambled eggs.
method.supplementary: Guanciale or Pancetta is traditional for Carbonara, but thick-cut bacon can be used if unavailable. Be careful not to overcook the garlic or the sauce may become bitter. Keep the pasta moving when mixed with the egg mixture to avoid cooking the eggs.

result.outcome: The Carbonara has a lighter sauce with a creamy texture that stays smooth longer, and the Bucatini provides a dense, chewy pasta experience.

problem.goal: To make a foolproof carbonara that is luscious, creamy, and full of flavor.

method.procedure:
1. Toast black peppercorns over medium-low heat until fragrant and popping, then cool and crush them.
2. Gather all ingredients within arm's reach.
3. Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane for fine texture.
4. Prepare room temperature eggs by using three whole eggs and two yolks, and mix them with grated cheese to form a homogeneous mixture.
5. Add toasted black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture.
6. Cut guanciale into thick matchstick pieces.
7. Boil salted water and cook spaghetti pasta until al dente.
8. Cook guanciale in a pan with a little olive oil until light golden brown.
9. Drain pasta, leaving some pasta water, and mix it in a bowl with the egg and cheese mixture.
10. Add cooked guanciale and its fat to the bowl and mix thoroughly to emulsify the sauce around the pasta.

result.outcome: The carbonara is creamy and silky with a rich, emulsified sauce coating the pasta. The guanciale adds a chewy texture and savory flavor, complemented by the spiciness of the black pepper and the sharpness and earthiness of the cheeses. The dish is ready to be served hot and enjoyed immediately.

problem.subgoal: Introduce the process of making foolproof carbonara.
problem.context: The audience is about to learn how to make carbonara and may perceive it as complicated.

method.tools: No tools used in this step.
method.instructions: Introduce yourself and explain the goal of the video: to make foolproof carbonara.
method.explanations: The introduction sets the stage for the video by establishing the speaker's credentials and the aim to simplify the carbonara-making process.
method.supplementary: Reassure the audience that carbonara is easy with the right techniques.

result.outcome: The audience understands the purpose of the video and feels confident that they can make carbonara easily by following the techniques provided.

problem.subgoal: Toast black peppercorns for carbonara.
problem.context: The cook is preparing ingredients for carbonara and is about to toast black peppercorns before grinding them.

method.instructions: Place black peppercorns in a pan over medium-low heat. Stir them around until they become fragrant and start to move or pop. Once you hear the first pop, remove from heat and let them cool on a tray.
method.explanations: Toasting the peppercorns enhances their flavor by giving them a nutty, deep aroma, which improves the overall taste of the carbonara.
method.supplementary: Ensure you stir the peppercorns to toast them evenly and avoid overcooking by removing them from heat after the first pop.

result.outcome: The peppercorns are toasted, fragrant, and ready to be cooled before grinding for use in carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Grate cheese using a microplane for carbonara.
problem.context: The peppercorns have been toasted and crushed, and now the cheese needs to be grated for making carbonara.

method.instructions: Use a microplane to grate parmesan and pecorino cheese finely.
method.explanations: Grating the cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly into the sauce, creating a silky texture. Parmesan adds nuttiness and earthiness, while pecorino adds sharpness and bite.
method.supplementary: Choose high-quality Italian cheeses for the best flavor. Grating your own cheese enhances the dish's quality.

result.outcome: Finely grated cheese ready to be incorporated into the carbonara sauce, enhancing its flavor and texture.

problem.subgoal: Prepare room temperature eggs and mix with grated cheese for carbonara sauce.
problem.context: The cheese is grated and ready to be mixed with eggs to create the carbonara sauce.

method.instructions: Set eggs on the counter for about half an hour to reach room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two egg yolks into a bowl. Add the grated cheese to the eggs. Use a whisk to combine the mixture until smooth and creamy. Add toasted black pepper to taste.
method.explanations: Using room temperature eggs ensures they mix more easily with the hot pasta without scrambling. The combination of whole eggs and extra yolks increases the sauce's richness and creaminess. Mixing cheese with eggs creates the base of the carbonara sauce, which should be smooth to avoid lumps when combined with pasta.
method.supplementary: Ensure the eggs are fully mixed with the cheese to avoid scrambled eggs when combined with hot pasta. Adjust the amount of black pepper to taste.

result.outcome: A smooth, creamy egg and cheese mixture ready to be combined with pasta to create a silky carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Boil salted water and cook pasta

problem.subgoal: Prepare the guanciale for carbonara.
problem.context: The chef has all ingredients within arm's reach and the pasta is boiling in salted water.

method.instructions: Turn on the heat and add a little olive oil to the pan. Add the guanciale and cook until it is light golden brown, stirring occasionally.
method.explanations: Adding olive oil helps the guanciale brown more evenly and quickly, without waiting for the fat to render out. Cooking until light golden brown ensures the guanciale retains some chewiness rather than becoming crispy.
method.supplementary: Do not overcook the guanciale to keep it chewy and ensure all the fat is retained for the sauce.

result.outcome: The guanciale is cooked to a light golden brown, retaining its chewiness and fat, ready to be mixed into the pasta for carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Cook guanciale in a pan until light golden brown.
problem.context: The pan is heated and a little olive oil has been added.

method.instructions: 1. Heat the pan on the stove. 2. Add a little olive oil to the pan. 3. Place the guanciale in the pan. 4. Cook until the guanciale is light golden brown and sizzling.
method.explanations: Adding olive oil helps the guanciale brown more evenly and quickly by starting the cooking process before the fat renders. The goal is to cook it until light golden brown to maintain some chewiness and retain all the fat, which is essential for the dish.
method.supplementary: Do not cook the guanciale until it is crispy; it should remain chewy. Retain all the fat as it is important for emulsifying with egg yolks to create a creamy sauce.

result.outcome: The guanciale is lightly browned, chewy, and sizzling, with all the fat retained for use in the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix with egg and cheese mixture

problem.subgoal: Combine cooked pasta with egg and cheese mixture to create carbonara sauce.
problem.context: The pasta is cooked to al dente, and the egg and cheese mixture is prepared and ready.

method.tools: Pasta pot, tongs, mixing bowl, whisk
method.instructions: Drain the pasta but leave some pasta water. Add the pasta directly into the egg and cheese mixture. Add the cooked guanciale and its fat. Use tongs to mix thoroughly until the sauce is creamy.
method.explanations: The residual heat from the pasta will gently cook the eggs, preventing scrambling and creating a creamy sauce. The pasta water helps emulsify the sauce, and the fat from the guanciale adds flavor and richness.
method.supplementary: Be cautious not to scramble the eggs by ensuring the pasta is not too hot and mixing quickly. Adjust the consistency of the sauce with pasta water if needed.

result.outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy, rich carbonara sauce with emulsified cheese and guanciale fat, ready to serve.

problem.subgoal: Serve the carbonara while hot and ready.
problem.context: The carbonara sauce has been mixed with the pasta, guanciale, and its fat, creating a creamy and rich dish.

method.instructions: Serve the carbonara immediately, ensuring to include some of each ingredient in each serving.
method.explanations: Serving the dish while hot ensures the sauce remains creamy and the flavors are at their peak. Mixing ensures each bite has a balanced taste of all ingredients.
method.supplementary: Carbonara is best enjoyed hot, as the texture and flavor degrade when cooled.

result.outcome: The dish is served hot, with a balanced portion of pasta, sauce, guanciale, and cheese in each serving, ready to be enjoyed.
